unnormalised: The prevalence of common childhood ailments, such as respiratory infections like bronchiolitis caused by RSV, gastrointestinal disorders, and vaccine-preventable diseases, necessitates a robust pediatric healthcare infrastructure. Polio, though largely eradicated, remains a concern until global eradication is achieved. Nutritional deficiencies, particularly iron deficiency anemia, are also widespread, impacting cognitive development and overall health. The National Immunization Programme (NIP) aims to provide free vaccines against preventable diseases, targeting millions of children annually.

unnormalised: Advances in pediatric medicine have led to improved diagnostic tools and treatment modalities. Neonatal Intensive Care Units (NICUs) equipped with ventilators and incubators are becoming increasingly common in hospitals like AIIMS Delhi and CMC Vellore, providing critical care for premature and sick newborns. The use of antibiotics, however, requires careful monitoring to avoid antibiotic resistance, a growing global concern. A study published in the Indian Journal of Pediatrics showed that 60% of pediatricians in Mumbai prescribe antibiotics for viral infections.

unnormalised: Several government initiatives focus on improving child health indicators. The Integrated Child Development Services (ICDS) scheme aims to provide early childhood care and nutrition to children under 6 years of age. The Rashtriya Bal Swasthya Karyakram (RBSK) screens children for common health conditions and provides early intervention services. These programs aim to reduce the infant mortality rate (IMR) and under-five mortality rate (U5MR), which, despite improvements, remain higher than in developed countries.

unnormalised: The role of pediatricians extends beyond clinical care to include health education and advocacy. Dr. Anita Sharma, a leading pediatrician in Bangalore, emphasizes the importance of parental counseling on breastfeeding, nutrition, and child development. Awareness campaigns are crucial in promoting healthy lifestyle choices and preventing childhood obesity, a growing concern in urban areas. The Indian Academy of Pediatrics (IAP) plays a key role in setting standards for pediatric care and promoting research in the field.

unnormalised: Challenges remain in ensuring equitable access to quality pediatric care, particularly in rural areas. Shortages of trained pediatricians, limited access to specialized services, and socioeconomic disparities continue to hinder progress. Strengthening primary healthcare systems, improving infrastructure, and investing in human resources are crucial steps towards achieving optimal child health outcomes for all children in India. The next national health survey due in 2025 will provide an updated view of pediatric healthcare access.
